# Satellite images reveal Iran quietly concealing nuclear damage while hardening sites underground

The images show that Iran has erected large roofs over damaged structures at both Natanz and Isfahan to conceal the extent of destruction and ongoing recovery operations

[![Ajish P Joy](https://img.theweek.in/content/dam/week/authorimages/ajish-p-joy.jpg.image.31.44.jpg)](https://www.theweek.in/authors.Ajish-Joy.html "Ajish P Joy")[By Ajish P Joy](https://www.theweek.in/authors.Ajish-Joy.html "Ajish P Joy")Updated: January 31, 2026 09:32 IST

![This satellite image from Planet Labs PBC shows the Pilot Fuel Enrichment Planet covered by a new roof at Iran's Natanz nuclear enrichment site | AP](https://img.theweek.in/etc.clientlibs/theweek/global-clientlibs/clientlibs-general/resources/images/week-default.jpg)This satellite image from Planet Labs PBC shows the Pilot Fuel Enrichment Planet covered by a new roof at Iran's Natanz nuclear enrichment site \| AP

**_For latest news and analyses on Middle East, [visit: Yello! Middle East](https://www.theweek.in/specials/middle-east.html)_**

Recent high-resolution satellite imagery captured by Planet Labs PBC has revealed significant activity at Iran’s primary nuclear facilities at Natanz and Isfahan, both of which were targeted during the “12-day war” in June involving Israeli and American airstrikes. The images show that Iran has erected large roofs over damaged structures at both sites, a move widely interpreted by intelligence analysts as an effort to conceal the extent of destruction and ongoing recovery operations.

At the Natanz nuclear complex, satellite images indicate that a roof was constructed in December over the Pilot Fuel Enrichment Plant, a facility previously used to enrich uranium. A similar structure was completed in early January at the Isfahan Nuclear Technology Centre, covering a damaged building near the site’s northeast corner.
